learning_outcomes.description: Identify infectious agents of veterinary importance and describe the pathogenesis and epidemiology of infectious diseases in individual animals and groups of animals.
Design and justify differential diagnoses and diagnostic strategies for infectious diseases, including the selection, performance, interpretation, and limitations of diagnostic tests.
Develop and justify immediate and longer‑term treatment, prevention, and control plans for infectious diseases, including appropriate antimicrobial and parasiticide use and stewardship principles.
Identify and assess zoonotic and public‑health risks and provide evidence‑based advice to owners, managers, and stakeholders using One Health and biosecurity principles.
Explain and apply biosecurity, biosafety, infection‑control principles, and the fundamentals of emergency response to animal diseases, including recognition of notifiable and reportable conditions.
Demonstrate core vocational laboratory and diagnostic skills, including sample collection, test performance, data interpretation, and accurate reporting.
Communicate diagnostic reasoning and infectious‑disease information clearly and accurately in written assessments and during supervised practical activities.
Integrate theoretical knowledge and practical skills from the program thus far to investigate and reason through infectious‑disease cases as preparation for clinical‑year decision‑making.

assessments.task_description:
Students will be examined on all parasitology and parasiticide lectures, practicals, and tutorials. In addition to content‑focused questions, the exam will include case‑based questions that require students to apply parasitology knowledge to clinical or investigative scenarios, including differential diagnoses, selection and interpretation of diagnostic tests, and basic treatment or control planning.

This will be an on-campus invigilated examination hosted on Inspera. The exam duration is 100 mins including 10 mins planning time. 

Exam questions may also include: multiple response, text entry, matching/pairing, inline choice, drag and drop, composite, hotspot and matching and case‑based applied reasoning items.

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
Students will complete five parasitology practical classes, each focusing on key parasitology diagnostic skills.

  • At each practical, there will be a short in‑class assessment task worth 1.25%.
  • To allow flexibility, the best 4 out of 5 marks will count toward your final grade (total 5%).


All work submitted must be the student’s own. Collusion during practical quizzes constitutes academic misconduct.

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Assessments will be submitted during the scheduled practical sessions.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
This examination will assess two components:

Part A – Virology (60 mins) (15%)

This section examines content from virology lectures and tutorials. It will assess your understanding of viral pathogens, their associated diseases, diagnostic principles, and approaches to management.

Part B – Integrated Case‑Based Assessment (30 mins) (5%)

  • This section requires you to apply knowledge from both virology and parasitology in realistic clinical scenarios. You will work through cases that involve identifying likely infectious agents, developing differential diagnoses, selecting and interpreting diagnostic tests, and proposing appropriate treatment and control plans.


This will be an on-campus invigilated examination hosted on Inspera. The exam duration is 100 mins including 10 mins planning time.

Exam questions may also include: multiple response, text entry, matching/pairing, inline choice, drag and drop, composite, hotspot and matching, and case‑based applied‑reasoning items.  

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
Students will be examined on all bacteriology lectures, tutorials, practical classes, and antimicrobial chemotherapy content. In addition to content‑focused questions, the exam will include case‑based questions that require students to apply bacteriology knowledge to clinical or investigative scenarios. These may involve developing differential diagnoses, selecting and interpreting diagnostic tests, and proposing basic antimicrobial treatment or control strategies.

This will be an on-campus invigilated examination hosted on Inspera. The exam duration is 70 mins including 10 mins planning time. 

Exam questions may also include: multiple response, text entry, matching/pairing, inline choice, drag and drop, composite, hotspot and matching, and case‑based applied reasoning items. 

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
Students will be examined on all bacteriology and mycology lectures, tutorials, practical classes, and antimicrobial chemotherapy content. The exam will also assess material from the Public Health, Zoonoses, and Integration lectures, tutorials, as well as the Biosecurity Workshop.

In addition to content‑focused questions, the exam may include items that require students to apply microbiology and public health knowledge to clinical, epidemiological, and biosecurity scenarios. These may involve developing differential diagnoses, interpreting diagnostic results, evaluating antimicrobial selection, and applying principles of population health, zoonoses, and biosecurity.

This will be an on-campus invigilated examination hosted on Inspera. The exam duration is 100 mins including 10 mins planning time. 

Exam questions may also include: multiple response, text entry, matching/pairing, inline choice, drag and drop, composite, hotspot and matching, as well as applied reasoning items.  

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
This open‑book practical examination assesses students’ clinical reasoning and their ability to integrate knowledge across bacteriology, virology, mycology, and parasitology. The exam evaluates both theoretical understanding and practical competence in diagnosing and managing infectious diseases.

Students will complete two case studies, each comprising written and/or practical components.

Part A - Written component (5%) - 30 minutes

Based on the case scenario provided, students must:

  1. Compose a differential diagnosis list including FIVE (5) infectious agents only.
  2. Describe the samples that should be collected to make a diagnosis and explain:
  3. how the samples should be managed in‑clinic/on‑farm (correct handling procedures), and
  4. what tests the diagnostic laboratory should perform.
  5. (One case only) Complete the Veterinary Laboratory Services (VLS) sample request form, including all relevant information and required tests.


Part B- Laboratory Practical Skills (10%) - 60 minutes

  • Students will perform a set of diagnostic skills relevant to their case scenario across bacteriology, virology, mycology, and parasitology. They will also be assessed on OHS, laboratory practice, accuracy of technique, and correct recording/reporting of findings.


Hurdle: Must achieve ≥50% in Part B to pass the course


Part C - Written Component (5%) - 30 minutes

Students will be provided with a diagnostic report for each case. For both cases, students must:

  1. Provide the final diagnosis.
  2. Provide the prognosis.
  3. Describe the final treatment and management plan based on the report findings.


Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.
